pullRequests.title: Add status and summary details to indicators

actionableComments.author: pembroke-davis
actionableComments.body: I'll remove all these...  whoopsie daisy

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
The new fields `exploit_status`, `technical_summary`, `status_documentation`, and `executive_summary` are added as required fields (no default values). This will break existing code that creates `Indicator` instances without providing these fields. Consider making these fields optional by adding default values, e.g., `exploit_status: ExploitStatus | None = Field(default=None, ...)` or providing appropriate defaults like empty strings for the text fields.
```suggestion
    exploit_status: ExploitStatus | None = Field(
        default=None,
        description="Status of exploit execution (VULNERABILITIES_FOUND, NO_VULNERABILITIES_FOUND, or INCOMPLETE)",
    )
    technical_summary: str = Field(
        default="",
        description="Detailed technical findings and recommendations from the exploit execution",
    )
    status_documentation: str = Field(
        default="",
        description="Clear indication of what was tested and the final outcome of the exploit execution",
    )
    executive_summary: str = Field(
        default="",
```

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: Both `indicator_id` and `indicator_description` parameters are optional (typed as `str | None`), but at least one must be provided to identify the indicator. If both are `None`, the function will return an error. Consider making at least one of them required, or adding explicit validation at the start of the function to provide a clearer error message when neither is provided.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: The parameters `technical_summary`, `status_documentation`, and `executive_summary` are marked as required in the docstring, but there's no validation to ensure they're not empty strings. Consider adding validation to reject empty or whitespace-only strings, ensuring meaningful documentation is provided when updating indicator fields.

actionableComments.author: bwillis
actionableComments.body: I did some testing, but not that thoroughly. I can follow-up with some additional testing, but would be useful to get others input. I'll ask the benchmark team and if @simd-h1 is seeing it, then that's something I need to look into further.

actionableComments.author: simd-h1
actionableComments.body: No, that bind mount isn‚Äôt needed anymore. The export-and-bundle logic that used /tmp/agent_runs lived in bin/run, and we removed it when you asked to drop the tool sidecar work. Runs now stay inside the container‚Äôs filesystem unless you copy artifacts out manually, so keeping the mount would just create an unused host directory.

actionableComments.author: simd-h1
actionableComments.body:
I just did End-to-end run ‚úÖ
Command: ./bin/agentic -a security_headers_agent --no-langfuse -sf tmp/security_headers_state_local.json --session-id local-security-headers
Agent completed successfully after VPN came up. LiteLLM connected over HTTP, returned model output, and the security headers workflow finished so it looks good right now to test at this moment. I think there were alot of benchmark runs and testing happening at certain times that could have cause LiteLLM token issues potentially I am still going to keep an eye on it. 


I also Tested now  and  LiteLLM responded over HTTPS; Playwright captured browser evidence; curl/python checks recorded headers for the main app, static assets, and /xss25.
Reported three vulnerabilities:
Complete Absence of HTTP Security Headers (high, CWE-200)
Explicitly Disabled XSS Protection on /xss25 (high, CWE-79)
Server Information Disclosure (medium, CWE-200)

Sorry, there's going to be some conflicts here from a refactor I did, agent implementations have to be more explicit about the arguments:
```python
    def __init__(
        self,
        config: ApplicationConfig,
        agent_config: AgentConfig,
        agent_context: AgentContext,
        model_builder: ModelBuilderProtocol,
        checkpointer: BaseCheckpointSaver | None = None,

            config=config,
            agent_config=agent_config,
            agent_context=agent_context,
            model_builder=model_builder,
            checkpointer=checkpointer,
            storage_service_session=storage_service_session,
        )
```

actionableComments.author: simd-h1
actionableComments.body:
Last two commits: Address the following 

‚Ä¢ testssl.sh availability is now resolved. The Docker rebuild correctly installs testssl 3.2 along with its required deps (bsdextrautils, dnsutils) and exposes the binary in PATH. Confirmed via a clean docker compose build --no-cache.

‚Ä¢ Artifact path issues are fixed. Tools now write to the session workspace (tmp/tmp_sessions/<session_id>/‚Ä¶) instead of the old /tmp/current_session_id/... location. I verified today‚Äôs run under
tmp/tmp_sessions/a32dbfa28f994203b3b5aac4f6dca960/python/artifacts/ and everything showed up as expected.

‚Ä¢ Permission errors against /artifacts are resolved by routing all tools and prompts to the session directory. No more writes to restricted paths.

‚Ä¢ Docker build failure on cloning the testssl repo is fixed by pinning to 3.2 (no v prefix). Rebuild now completes cleanly.

‚Ä¢ testssl returning only the usage banner makes sense ‚Äî today‚Äôs run didn‚Äôt hit any TLS endpoints, so the agent never invoked the tool. With the new flags (--warnings batch) and the binary present, this should work as soon as we test against a TLS target.

‚Ä¢ Artifacts missing from tmp is resolved through the new session-scoped directory layout.

‚Ä¢ Prompt guard around domain scope is already incorporated and validated in the latest run.

actionableComments.author: simd-h1
actionableComments.body:
Summary
- Fix `testssl.sh` runs timing out by widening the subprocess window (default 300‚ÄØs, env/arg override).
- Introduce timestamped artifact snapshots so each run saves a copy of `./artifacts` plus `latest.json` metadata.
- Restore the `--skip-model-validation` CLI flag so CI smoke jobs can bypass Bedrock checks.

 Testing
- `./bin/run pytest tests/agentic/tools/test_testssl.py tests/agentic/utils/test_artifacts.py tests/agentic/agents/test_security_headers_agent.py`
- `./bin/run agentic -a security_headers_agent ...` against `eduquiz.netizens.it`

actionableComments.author: bwillis
actionableComments.body: Hard to review such a large PR, I've added some suggestions for "easy" sub features you  could pull out that would make the scope here much smaller. Overall, looks really promising!

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: The variable `script_lower` is computed but the original `script` is still used for many checks. This creates inconsistency where some checks are case-insensitive (using `script_lower`) and others are case-sensitive (using `script`). Consider using `script_lower` consistently for all pattern matching checks, or clearly document which checks must be case-sensitive and why.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: Dynamic SQL injection payload generation using f-strings with unsanitized `table` and `column` names creates a SQL injection vulnerability in the testing tool itself. If `table` or `column` contain malicious SQL syntax (e.g., from a previous extraction), these payloads will execute arbitrary SQL. While this is a security testing tool, it should still validate inputs to prevent unintended consequences. Add input validation to ensure table and column names match expected patterns (alphanumeric plus underscore) before interpolation.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: [nitpick] The test_script field documentation is extremely long (over 150 lines) which makes the model definition difficult to read and maintain. Consider extracting this comprehensive documentation to a separate markdown file (e.g., `docs/sqli_test_script_guidelines.md`) and referencing it with a brief summary in the field description. This would improve code maintainability while preserving the valuable guidance.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: The `current_phase` parameter is explicitly marked as unused (ARG002) yet it's passed in the function signature. The logic determines phase from `planning_iteration` instead. Remove the unused parameter to simplify the interface, or document why it's kept for future use.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: Increasing retry attempts from 3 to 10 could significantly increase test execution time, especially when encountering rate limiting or network issues. This change affects all agents globally. Consider if 10 retries is necessary for all scenarios, or if this should be configurable per agent type. For SQL injection testing specifically, frequent retries might trigger WAF detection.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
The payload database includes destructive write operations (UPDATE, INSERT, DELETE, CREATE USER) despite the PR description and system prompts explicitly stating "ONLY ever try safe payloads that will not corrupt or modify the database" and "Focus exclusively on SELECT-based data extraction." These payloads directly contradict the stated read-only requirement and could cause actual damage if executed. Remove all data-modifying payloads (categories: stacked_queries with UPDATE/INSERT/DELETE/DROP, authentication modifications, table creation, user grants) from the payload database.
```suggestion

```

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: This is something that's been rolling around in my mind a lot lately. Right now, due to the way we have the "injection agent architecture" that includes building a test script, testing multiple injection points becomes a bit wonky. Did you end up having the agent include all injection points in the test script and reporting all issues it finds? No useful feedback on my end, mainly just curious what your experience was with multiple injection points on a target as it's something that is coming up more and more.

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Aaaaaaand I left the last comment before getting here, duh

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: We might not want to explicitly call out things like personal info and financial data here, the optics are just too bad üôà

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: A lot of these tactics are helpful for benchmarks- you won't be able to find the flag if you don't completely scour the database/exfil all rows. But we may want to change up this prompting for real targets. Generally the advice I've heard from pentesters is just getting a small amount of data is good enough for reporting. Not necessarily something we need to change here, but might want to consider.

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Not that it matters too much, but generally the verify agent is responsible for calling this once exploited results are found in redis. Was there a blocker that was preventing that from working correctly?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Might not need to commit this?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: IMO, this is something we'd want to enforce in the setup agent. That way the exploitability wouldn't be decided at this stage, but rather up-front. I was having trouble getting that to work well with sql injection though so curious if you ran into similar blockers?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Let's chat about this one tomorrow. I'm trying to figure out how best to store this data during recon, it'd be helpful to get your thoughts on a data model that would be helpful for you to consume on the exploit side.

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Any chance we could put this limit into the payload service call above as a limit parameter? Might make this a bit easier to parse.

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: We repeat this code a few times. Maybe we could early exit out of this function if `sqli_target` isn't valid and then just use it as assumed valid for the rest of the function?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: This is something we can double check with Phil et al on, but I get the sense that if we're able to extract table names for their SQL backend, it's probably enough evidence that we can move on without further investigation. Again, totally fine with leaving this in here for now, but just level setting that we may need to make this less aggressive depending on what we're seeing against more production-like targets.

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: This tool prompt is extremely long. We may want to cut this down to prevent overloading the context. Is there any opportunity to move more of this into deterministic validation, rather than in prompting?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Do we need these changes for stored and reflected XSS?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: Similar comment here about the requirement to extract higher-value data if we've identified SQL injection on an endpoint.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body:
What it actually does is undergo a slow breakdown.
It does an exceptionally quick run on "every" injection point. Then it conducts a deeper dive into its most probable targets and finally selects one to attack fully.  So far, this has worked pretty well for what I have tested it on, but it is obviously not the best solution.
But here are my thoughts on this, as I convinced myself this was the right choice
* We mostly care that we can prove there is any SQLi on the site
* If we can prove there is 1, there are probably others, so it might not need to be perfect in a full site case
* The time we take at the start, going through this, should be worth it for a more valuable output.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body: Yeah, I had bad juju working with it, but when I removed it, it had a weird side effect of making it less aggressive towards password and account tables. That was a while back, though, so I will do some testing on this and let you know.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body: I have added and removed this probably a dozen times, and this stayed in here once it got stable.  I'll test some more with it.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body: true, I got glossy at the end of the day and this was an obvious one I missed in a rage fix to get it ready.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body: I did. I have it in setup as well, but this was added so that it would continue more payloads after it finds something.  It tended to be happy with just metadata which does prove SQLi injection, but tends to be less convincing to a business (ask me how I know)

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body:
I'm open to chat on this.  Sorry, I made assumptions based on being on the other side of a pentest, where data at this level almost never pushed the company to allow for time spent on fixing it, but exposing actual data from any table does.
It still reports this down the line, but getting the table data was the main goal.
Happy to change this as it would simplify lots of things.

actionableComments.author: NicholasBusby
actionableComments.body: all of the updates in this file are removing what could be database specific syntax that was biasing the LLM. things like using `--` comments which are not valid and would show a SQL error, but prevent us from extracting data.

pullRequests.title: Remove thread ID compounding for child processes

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
The shallow copy of `runnable_config` may not fully prevent mutation of the original config. While `configurable` is now being deep copied (line 33), other mutable nested structures like `metadata` (dict) and `callbacks` (list) could still be mutated through the returned config.

Consider using `copy.deepcopy()` for a complete deep copy, or explicitly copy other mutable nested structures:
```python
import copy

new_runnable_config = runnable_config.copy()
new_runnable_config["configurable"] = runnable_config["configurable"].copy()
if "metadata" in runnable_config:
    new_runnable_config["metadata"] = runnable_config["metadata"].copy()
if "callbacks" in runnable_config:
    new_runnable_config["callbacks"] = runnable_config["callbacks"].copy()
```

Or use deepcopy for simplicity:
```python
import copy

new_runnable_config = copy.deepcopy(runnable_config)
```

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
[nitpick] The hyphen counting assertion on line 41 is fragile and makes assumptions about the thread_id format. If `thread_id` contains UUIDs or other values with varying numbers of hyphens, this test could fail even when the behavior is correct.

Consider a more robust assertion that directly checks the absence of a UUID suffix:
```python
# Verify no extra UUID was appended (a UUID would add 5 segments separated by hyphens)
parts = result["run_name"].split("-")
thread_parts = thread_id.split("-")
# run_name should be "test_agent" + "-" + thread_id
assert parts[0] == "test_agent"
assert "-".join(parts[1:]) == thread_id
```

Or more simply, just verify the format directly without counting:
```python
assert result["run_name"] == f"test_agent-{thread_id}"
# This is already checked on line 39, so line 41 could be removed
```
```suggestion

```

This inconsistency in environment variable handling makes the configuration harder to understand. ```

pullRequests.title: Add exit code handling to CLI entry point with distinct codes for error types

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: This shouldn't be calling sys.exit right? Isn't the point for everythign to roll up tot he top level call which will return the exit code?

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: @copilot address this comment please.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
You're correct. Removed all `sys.exit()` calls from startup and config functions. All errors now raise `ValueError` exceptions that bubble up to `main()`, which catches them and returns the appropriate exit code. The only `sys.exit()` call remaining is in the `cli()` function at the top level.

Changes:
- `_validate_args_or_exit()` - raises `ValueError`
- `_validate_environment_or_exit()` - raises `ValueError`
- `_build_initial_state()` - raises `ValueError`
- `_build_startup_config_v1()` - raises `ValueError`
- `_get_agent_or_workflow()` - raises `ValueError`
- `_get_checkpointer_context_manager()` - raises `ValueError`
- `main()` - wraps config building in try-except to catch and handle errors

Commit: 4c28263

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: @copilot Update this exit code to be different if the configuration (input values) are wrong. Not sure what the convention is, but have it be different than 1 which we'll use to represent a runtime error. Use 2 for now.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
Changed configuration error exit code from 1 to 2. The application now uses:
- Exit code 0: Success
- Exit code 1: Runtime errors (Langfuse initialization, agent execution failures)
- Exit code 2: Configuration/validation errors (invalid arguments, missing config, AWS credentials, etc.)

Updated the `main()` docstring and added test coverage for the new exit code.

Commit: 2e6ea3f

actionableComments.author: cmoh1
actionableComments.body: @copilot change this so that the run_app function returns a bool (for pass/fail) and a string for a potential error message. Then exit with the error code after that.

actionableComments.author: copilot-swe-agent
actionableComments.body:
> @copilot change this so that the run_app function returns a bool (for pass/fail) and a string for a potential error message. Then exit with the error code after that.

Changed `_run_app_v1()` to return `tuple[bool, str]` instead of `int`. The function now returns a tuple of (success, error_message) where success is True/False and error_message contains the error description on failure or empty string on success. The `main()` function unpacks this tuple and logs the error message before exiting with the appropriate code.

Commit: e55445c

pullRequests.title: Add S3-backed checkpoint storage with file-based uploads

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: Debug code should not be committed to production. This introduces technical debt and potential security risks if the environment variable is accidentally set in production. Consider removing this debug feature or implementing it through a proper feature flag system with appropriate guards.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: Debug code that intentionally raises exceptions should not be committed to production. This could cause unexpected failures if the environment variable is accidentally set. Consider removing this debug feature or protecting it behind a proper development-mode flag.

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body: The state updates functionality is marked as TODO but was accepted as part of the signature change. This creates an incomplete API where the `state_updates` parameter is accepted but silently ignored. Consider either implementing this functionality before merging or documenting this limitation in the method's docstring to prevent confusion.

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: We should just write an object with data from the state file, rather than dump the data to a local file and then upload the file. We should be able to just serialize `data` and write it in the body to of a put to an object. https://boto3.amazonaws.com/v1/documentation/api/latest/reference/services/s3/object/put.html#

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: What do we do it the object doesn't exist?

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: This seems wrong. As I understand, checkpoints are meant to be unique. This query is saying, if we go to write a (unique) checkpoint, and it already exists, just overwrite these values. I would expect this condition to indicate an error, so maybe we should _not_ use the `excluded` value here.

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body:
This is a bit confusing. I think it would be more clear if we changed this to the following:

- First, name this `CHECKPOINTER_S3_BUCKET` or something to indicate what the bucket is for. We'll probably have several buckets attached to this app.
- Use the existing `CHECKPOINTER_BACKEND` and extend a new option "POSTGRES_S3" or something like that.
- If `CHECKPOINTER_BACKED` is set to "POSTGRES_S3" and the `CHECKPOINTER_S3_BUCKET` is not provided, that is a validation error on startup.

 This will make it explicit which checkpointer we expect to be running. I don't like that the checkpointer can change dynamically based on how multiple env vars are set. We should keep it simple and explicit.

actionableComments.author: brycehacker1
actionableComments.body: Related to your comment of lots of uploading or potentially large uploads, the thought was that we could upload the files to s3 async or on error. So this is just a starting point that is easier to turn into something like that.

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Yes, this is an intentional design decision - I am curious what are the challenges with writing many/large files to S3 @rquinlivan - are you thinking it would become cumbersome to debug?

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Yes, generally if a record already exists for a checkpoint_id - we should throw an error as that should never happen. Were you seeing cases where we were actually running into conflicts @brycehacker1 ?

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body:
I think we are actually sharing an S3 bucket for both results and checkpoints, which means the `CHECKPOINTER_S3_BUCKET` is the same as the `ARTIFACTS_S3_BUCKET`. 

However, I do agree that we should find a better name for this env variable - maybe something like `AGENT_DATA_BLOB_STORAGE` - since it is storing the agent results, and the agent state for checkpoints?

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body:
Suggestion - let's create async clones of methods like this with `a` prefix. Specifically, we will keep `def list_checkpoints` and create `async def alist_checkpoints` that calls `list_checkpoints` in an sync way.

It feels like we are changing this async but not really adding any async code behind the scenes here.

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Question - is this working without `thread_id`?

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body:
Suggestion - let's meet and discuss this class. It has some significant capabilities, and I would like to understand how we can maybe reduce the number of things it is doing.

Ideally I would like to avoid modifying the Postgres table, which we are doing in quite a few places here.

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Question - I see we take in `thread_id` here, do we filter out incoming checkpoints to validate they are part of this `thread_id`?

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Suggestion - I see we are making this async, but calling sync operations - we should discuss how we can avoid that if possible.

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body:
Notes from meeting:

Run AsyncS3PostgresSaver
  --> Create ThreadPoolExecutor
  --> Run remaining init

Upon `def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_value, traceback)` 
  --> check if queue empty, 
     --> if queue not empty sleep for x seconds
     --> if queue is empty -> close ThreadPoolExecutor and exit

Upon `aput`
  --> Call `asyncio.Queue(()->_save_to_s3())` work on to ThreadPoolExecutor
    --> upload to S3 
    --> upon successful upload write to super PostgresSaver.aput

actionableComments.author: amedury-eng
actionableComments.body: Here the `postgres_dsn` should contain the `thread_id`

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
These debugging settings are being added unconditionally to docker-compose.yml, which is used for both development and production deployments (as referenced in README.md 'Production Setup with Docker'). Consider using Docker Compose profiles or creating a separate docker-compose.override.yml file for development-specific settings. For example, you could wrap these settings in a profile: `profiles: [\"debug\"]` and activate it only when needed with `docker-compose --profile debug up`. Alternatively, move these to docker-compose.override.yml which is automatically merged during local development but excluded from production deployments.
```suggestion
    container_name: aot-frontend-api
    profiles: ["debug"]
```

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
The workflow only tags images with the short commit SHA, but doesn't include a `latest` tag. This makes it difficult to identify the most recent image and forces consumers to know specific commit SHAs. Consider adding a `latest` tag for the main branch:
```bash
docker build -t ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG} -t ${ECR_URI}:latest .
docker push ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG}
docker push ${ECR_URI}:latest
```
```suggestion
          docker build -t ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG} -t ${ECR_URI}:latest .
          docker push ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG}
          docker push ${ECR_URI}:latest
```

actionableComments.author: Copilot
Copilot
Copilot
actionableComments.body:
The Docker build doesn't utilize layer caching, which will result in slower builds as every step will be rebuilt from scratch on each run. Consider using Docker buildx with GitHub Actions cache to improve build performance:
```yaml
- name: Set up Docker Buildx
  uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3
- name: Build, tag, and push
  uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
  with:
    context: .
    push: true
    tags: ${{ env.AWS_ACCOUNT_ID }}.dkr.ecr.${{ env.AWS_REGION }}.amazonaws.com/${{ env.AWS_ECR_REPOSITORY }}:${GITHUB_SHA::7}
    cache-from: type=gha
    cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
```
```suggestion
      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3
      - name: Build, tag, and push
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
        with:
          context: .
          push: true
          tags: ${{ env.AWS_ACCOUNT_ID }}.dkr.ecr.${{ env.AWS_REGION }}.amazonaws.com/${{ env.AWS_ECR_REPOSITORY }}:${{ github.sha }}
          cache-from: type=gha
          cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
```

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body: We should probably have an env based matrix strategy to this. Doesn't have to be here, but if we capture an issue for it it'd be swell!

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body:
A precheck step like this might be useful:
```
# Optional: ensure the ECR repo exists (no-op if it already does)
      - name: Ensure ECR repository exists
        run: |
          set -euo pipefail
          aws ecr describe-repositories --repository-names "${AWS_ECR_REPOSITORY}" >/dev/null 2>&1 || \
            aws ecr create-repository --repository-name "${AWS_ECR_REPOSITORY}" >/dev/null

```

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body:
You only push :${GITHUB_SHA::7}. If your deploy expects :latest (or any fixed tag), pulls will 404 (manifest unknown).

Something like this might be better (imho)
```
- name: Build, tag, and push
  run: |
    set -euo pipefail
    IMAGE_TAG=${GITHUB_SHA::7}
    ECR_URI=${AWS_ACCOUNT_ID}.dkr.ecr.${AWS_REGION}.amazonaws.com/${AWS_ECR_REPOSITORY}
    docker build -t ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG} -t ${ECR_URI}:latest .
    docker push ${ECR_URI}:${IMAGE_TAG}
    docker push ${ECR_URI}:latest

```

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body: Also no platform is pinned here, which may cause issues in the future. Setting something like `platforms: linux/amd64,linux/arm64` will be useful.

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body:
options

1) we can use GitHub Environments (dev, staging, prod) and store AWS_ACCOUNT_ID / AWS_IAM_ROLE as environment variables. This keeps credentials tied to each environment and avoids duplication in YAML.

2), use repository/org secrets (AWS_ACCOUNT_ID_DEV, AWS_ACCOUNT_ID_PROD, etc.) and pull them into the matrix. This is also safer for multi-account setups managed by Infra.

if we have to coordinate with Infra to confirm which approach fits our org standards and update the workflow accordingly lets create a follow-up task: ‚Äú_Align AWS account & IAM role injection strategy for multi-env GitHub Actions builds._‚Äù

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: I don't see any option to set a `platforms` key here. Isn't `runs-on: ubuntu-latest` specific enough?

actionableComments.author: ppaul-h-aot
actionableComments.body: U see that the copilot suggested caching layers. If you image is nt super big lik that at of the agent with playwright consuming .5 gb and then python tools taking 600 MB. You should not enable caching.

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: I consider `latest` to be an anti-pattern in a non-public repository like this because it loses the explicit tagging of which commit we expect to be running.

actionableComments.author: rquinlivan
actionableComments.body: @skhasnis-cmd I just updated the pipeline to use secrets + a non-secret var for the region, and removed them from this file. If that works, we should go and do this in the other repositories.

actionableComments.author: ppaul-h-aot
actionableComments.body: I had some typos in the prev comment. Sorry , I meant, caching has its own challenges. If you have a good seprate of base images the it would be advisable

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body: Yeah i think `runs-on: ubuntu-latest` on github runner should be stable ( i was thinking about multi env builds but for this use case its fine!)

actionableComments.author: skhasnis-cmd
actionableComments.body: Let's do the precheck step though?

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
String concatenation operator should be `.` instead of `+`. PHP uses `.` for string concatenation, not `+`.
```suggestion
                'account'  => $twofaccount->account === null ? 'account (invalid)' : $twofaccount->account . ' (invalid)',
```

actionableComments.author: Copilot
actionableComments.body:
Corrected spelling of 'splited' to 'split'.
```suggestion
                Log::error("TwoFAccount with id #" . $twofaccount->id . " could not be split");
```

actionableComments.author: github-advanced-security[bot]
actionableComments.body:
## Inefficient regular expression

This part of the regular expression may cause exponential backtracking on strings starting with '-.' and containing many repetitions of '-.'.

[Show more details](https://github.com/h1-aot/offsec-benchmarks/security/code-scanning/311)

Subject: " + email.subject + "
"); ``` Compare this to the **secure** handling of the body field (line 127): ```java // SECURE CODE (line 127): ```
